Comment:
Hi everyone!

I have a collection of games which seem to proove the fact that 2 pieces are better than one rook, even though the side that has the rook may also have a pawn or two for these pieces.  This is Example No.1.  I kick off with 1.e4.
2. ...... Nf6 - this is the Petrov's Defense, a counter-attack against the e4 pawn.
2. ...... Nf6 - this is the Petrov's Defense, a counter-attack against the e4 pawn.
2. ...... Nf6 - this is the Petrov's Defense, a counter-attack against the e4 pawn.
3. ...... Qe7 - skewers my knight against my e4 pawn and winning it very soon.
3. ...... Qe7 - skewers my knight against my e4 pawn and winning it very soon.
4. d4 - supports e5 knight and opens up a diagonal for Fou Lenoir.
5. Nc3 - development.
5. Nc3 - development.
6. ........ Qxe5 - after a knight trade on e5 black has now restored material equality.
